speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your gait and limb ataxia? Is it a gradual onset or did it start suddenly?

speaker: Patient
text: "It started a few weeks ago, I think. I was just walking to the store and I felt like I was stumbling, like my legs weren't cooperating with me. It's been getting worse since then."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any other symptoms besides the ataxia, such as numbness, tingling, or weakness in your limbs?

speaker: Patient
text: "I've noticed that my right arm feels a bit heavier than my left. It's like I have to think twice before lifting it. And sometimes, when I'm trying to do simple tasks like buttoning my shirt, my fingers feel like they're not responding properly."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any previous injuries or trauma to your head, neck, or spine?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't think so. I've had a few minor falls, but nothing that would cause this kind of... unsteadiness. And I've never had any major injuries or surgeries."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your medical history? Have you been diagnosed with any autoimmune disorders or neurological conditions in the past?

speaker: Patient
text: "I've been dealing with a chronic digestive issue for a while now. It's been a real challenge to manage, and I've had to try a few different treatments to find what works for me. But besides that, I don't think I've had any other major health issues."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your bowel habits or stool consistency recently?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, my digestive issues have been pretty stable lately. I've been on a consistent treatment plan and it's been working well for me. But to be honest, my main concern right now is this weird feeling in my legs and arms. It's really affecting my daily life and I'm getting worried."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your chronic digestive issue? What is the diagnosis and what treatment are you currently on?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's Crohn's disease. I was diagnosed about two years ago and I've been on natalizumab for the past year. It's been helping to manage my symptoms, but like I said, my main concern right now is this new problem with my gait and limb ataxia."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your experience with natalizumab? Have you noticed any side effects or changes in your symptoms while taking the medication?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's been working well for the most part, but I have noticed that I've been experiencing some... odd sensations, I guess you'd call them. It's like my body is just... off, somehow. But I didn't think much of it at first, just assumed it was part of the treatment. But this new thing with my legs and arms is definitely not normal."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe these "odd sensations" you've been experiencing while taking natalizumab? Are they constant or do they come and go?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's hard to explain, but sometimes I feel like my body is... numb, I guess. Like, I'll be sitting or lying down, and I'll feel like I'm not really connected to my limbs. It's not painful or anything, it's just... strange. And it happens randomly, sometimes it's constant for a few hours, and sometimes it comes and goes throughout the day."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when these numbness sensations started while taking natalizumab? Was it soon after you started the medication or did it develop over time?

speaker: Patient
text: "I think it started a few months into treatment. At first, I just wrote it off as my body adjusting to the medication, but it's been getting more frequent and intense lately. It's like my body is just... disconnecting from itself, or something. It's really unsettling."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've experienced any visual changes, such as blurred vision, double vision, or sensitivity to light?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, yes. Sometimes I get this weird feeling like I'm seeing double, like there are two of everything. It's usually when I'm trying to focus on something specific, like reading a book or watching TV. And sometimes, lights seem really bright and overwhelming, like they're bothering me more than usual."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when these visual changes started? Was it around the same time as the numbness sensations or did they develop separately? And have you experienced any changes in your sense of balance or coordination besides the ataxia?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's hard to pinpoint exactly when the visual changes started, but I think it was around the same time as the numbness sensations. Maybe a few months after I started taking natalizumab. And yeah, besides the ataxia, I've definitely noticed that my sense of balance is off. It's like my body is trying to compensate for something, but I'm not really sure what. Sometimes I feel like I'm going to fall over, even when I'm standing still. It's really disorienting."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation of feeling like you're going to fall over? Is it a constant feeling or does it come and go?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's definitely not constant, but it's definitely more frequent than I'd like. Sometimes I'll be walking down the hallway and I'll feel like I'm going to tip over, even though I'm standing straight up. It's like my body is trying to correct itself, but it's not quite getting it right. And it's not just when I'm moving, sometimes I'll be standing still and I'll feel like I'm going to fall over. It's really unsettling, like my body is just... off."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your Crohn's disease? Have you experienced any recent changes in your bowel habits or symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: "Well, to be honest, my Crohn's disease has been pretty stable lately. I've been on a consistent treatment plan and it's been working well for me. But like I said, my main concern right now is this weird feeling in my legs and arms. It's really affecting my daily life and I'm getting worried."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your recent lab work and blood tests for your Crohn's disease? Have you had any recent changes in your liver function tests or inflammatory markers?

speaker: Patient
text: "I'm not sure, I haven't really been paying attention to my lab work lately. I've been so focused on this new problem with my legs and arms. But I do remember my doctor mentioning that my inflammatory markers were a bit elevated last time I had a check-up. I think it was a few months ago. But I'm not sure if that's related to this new issue or not."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your doctor's concern regarding your inflammatory markers being elevated? Did they mention any specific treatment adjustments or changes they wanted to make based on those results?

speaker: Patient
text: "I think they just mentioned that it was something they wanted to keep an eye on, but I don't really remember any specific treatment adjustments or changes they wanted to make. Like I said, I've been so focused on this new problem with my legs and arms, I haven't really been paying attention to my Crohn's disease symptoms lately."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation of feeling like your body is disconnecting from itself? Is it a physical sensation or more of a mental or emotional feeling?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's hard to describe, but it's like... my body is just... separate from me, I guess. Like, I'm sitting there, and my arm is just... floating, or something. It's not like I can feel it, or control it, it's just... there. And it's not just my arms, it's my legs too. Sometimes I feel like I'm walking, but my legs aren't really moving. It's like... I'm just going through the motions, but my body is doing its own thing. It's really disorienting, and it makes me feel really anxious and scared."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when these feelings of disconnection started? Was it around the same time as the numbness sensations or did they develop separately?

speaker: Patient
text: "I think it started around the same time as the numbness sensations. Maybe a few months after I started taking natalizumab. It's like... my body was just... adjusting to the medication, or something. But it's been getting more frequent and intense lately. Sometimes I feel like I'm just... losing myself, or something. It's really scary."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation of feeling like you're losing yourself? Is it a feeling of identity loss or more of a sense of disconnection from your body?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's hard to explain, but it's like... I'm not really sure who I am anymore. Like, I'll be sitting there, and I'll think I'm just a normal person, and then suddenly I'll feel like I'm just a body, you know? Like, I'm not really in control of it. It's like... I'm just a passenger, or something. And it's not just the physical sensations, it's like... my mind is just... foggy, or something. I can't think straight, and I feel like I'm just... drifting through life. It's really scary, because I don't know what's happening to me."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the foggy feeling in your mind? Is it a constant feeling or does it come and go?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's definitely not constant, but it's definitely more frequent than I'd like. Sometimes I'll be trying to focus on something, like a conversation or a task, and my mind will just... go blank. It's like I'm not really thinking, I'm just... existing. And it's not just when I'm trying to focus, sometimes I'll be just sitting there, doing nothing, and I'll feel like my mind is just... foggy. It's hard to explain, but it's like... I'm not really sure what's going on, or what I'm supposed to be doing. It's really disorienting."

speaker: Doctor
text: REQUEST TEST: MRI of the brain and spine.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: MRI_Brain: Lesions consistent with Progressive Multifocal Encephalopathy (PML). T1/T2 images showing multifocal demyelinating lesions without gadolinium enhancement, indicative of PML.
